hypothesis.name: High Tilt and Southward Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: A high tilt angle (around 80°) combined with a southward azimuth (180°) is expected to capture maximum sunlight during peak hours.

hypothesis.name: Moderate Tilt with Eastward Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: A moderate tilt (30°) and an eastward azimuth (90°) may optimize morning sunlight capture, especially in summer months.

hypothesis.name: Balanced Configuration
hypothesis.rationale: A balanced approach with a tilt of 45° and azimuth of 180° aims to optimize energy capture throughout the day.

hypothesis.name: Low Tilt for Wider Exposure
hypothesis.rationale: A low tilt angle (10°) with a westward azimuth (270°) may be beneficial for capturing late afternoon sunlight.

hypothesis.name: High Capacity with Optimal Tilt
hypothesis.rationale: Maximizing system capacity (20 kW) with a tilt of 70° and azimuth of 150° could enhance overall energy production potential.

hypothesis.name: Moderate Tilt and Southward Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: Building on the successful configuration, a tilt around 70° with a southward azimuth is expected to maximize energy capture.

hypothesis.name: Optimized Tilt for Morning Capture
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of 60° with an azimuth of 90° may optimize energy capture during morning hours, complementing the previous findings.

hypothesis.name: Balanced Configuration with High Capacity
hypothesis.rationale: A balanced configuration with a tilt of 45° and azimuth of 180° aims to optimize energy capture throughout the day while maximizing system capacity.

hypothesis.name: Low Tilt for Late Afternoon Capture
hypothesis.rationale: A low tilt angle (15°) with a westward azimuth (270°) may capture late afternoon sunlight, although it may not be as effective as previous configurations.

hypothesis.name: High Capacity with Moderate Tilt
hypothesis.rationale: Maximizing system capacity (20 kW) with a tilt of 75° and azimuth of 150° could enhance overall energy production potential.

hypothesis.name: Optimized Tilt and Azimuth for Maximum Capture
hypothesis.rationale: Building on the successful configurations, a tilt of 75° with a southward azimuth of 180° is expected to maximize energy capture.

hypothesis.name: High Tilt with Slightly Eastward Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of 80° with an azimuth of 160° may capture energy effectively while still being close to the optimal range.

hypothesis.name: Moderate Tilt for Balanced Energy Capture
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of 70° and azimuth of 170° aims to balance energy capture throughout the day while maximizing system capacity.

hypothesis.name: Exploring Lower Tilt for Late Afternoon
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of 20° with a westward azimuth (270°) may capture late afternoon sunlight, although it is less likely to be effective compared to higher tilts.
